text.p: This problem demonstrates the use of a the “formula response" problem.

Let [mathjaxinline]f(x) = a x^2 + bx + c[/mathjaxinline]. Assume the coefficients [mathjaxinline]a[/mathjaxinline], [mathjaxinline]b[/mathjaxinline], and [mathjaxinline]c[/mathjaxinline] are positive. Give an equation for the positive root [mathjaxinline]\lambda[/mathjaxinline] such that [mathjaxinline]f(\lambda )=0[/mathjaxinline]:

Use ^ for exponentiation, e.g. x^2 denotes [mathjaxinline]x^2[/mathjaxinline]. Explicitly include multiplication using [mathjaxinline]{\tt *}[/mathjaxinline], e.g. [mathjaxinline]{\tt x*y}[/mathjaxinline] is [mathjaxinline]xy[/mathjaxinline]. Standard mathematical functions may be employed, e.g. [mathjaxinline]{\tt sin(x)}[/mathjaxinline], [mathjaxinline]{\tt sqrt(x)}[/mathjaxinline], etc.
